posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: SysID used to have a feature to run analysis on a drivetrain, but this has been removed. I’m wondering how teams are getting a single set of gains, given that each motor analysis has be run individually (of course there is also manual tuning.) Is this just a manually step to make an educated guess from the individual results?

posts.name: Joe Lockwood
posts.cooked:
Are you running CTRE swerve? If so, the CTRE PathPlanner example on GitHub has SysID in the drive subsystems.

If you are running CTRE and want to run TorqueCurrent, you must make a custom request.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Yes, we are using the CTRE library and we ran the routines. We have a log file with all of the drive motors. However, when loaded this into the SysID tool, each motor’s results have to be analyzed individually (unless I’m missing something.) How do you derive a single set of gains from the set of four gains?

image 475×891 66.9 KB

image 475×891 66.9 KB

image 475×891 66.9 KB

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
gdefender:

motor’s results have to be analyzed individually

Yes, because each motor will behave slightly different. This is a good thing, and you can apply the individual gains per motor in your TunerConstants file

posts.name: Joe Lockwood
posts.cooked: To follow up on this you should get very similar results for each module by tuning the time and max velocity.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
I suppose you could enter individual gains in TunerConstants , but it’s not set up that way out of the box. It has a single SlotConfigs used to create a single ConstantsCreator .

Phoenix library aside, how would you calculate your MOI with 4 sets of kA values, just average them?

joeojazz:

you should get very similar results

We do get very similar results, but not identical results. Do teams just choose what seems reasonable and then manually tune? I agree, if there’s a large variance, something is probably wrong with the test or the module. I’m just trying to see if I’m missing an available tool or well defined process.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked:
gdefender:

I’m just trying to see if I’m missing an available tool or well defined process.

I think most people are using a single set of gains across all 4 modules and assuming that they are mechanically close enough that it works out.
